items.title: Handmark
items.text: Handmark is a Python CLI tool that converts handwritten notes from images into structured documents. It supports multiple AI providers (Azure AI and Ollama) and output formats (Markdown, JSON, YAML, XML), making it easy to digitize handwritten content with flexible processing options.

items.title: Key Features
items.text: Multi-Format Document Generation Transform handwritten notes into Markdown, JSON, YAML, or XML Intelligent Title Extraction Automatically detects and extracts titles from content for smart file naming Easy CLI Interface Simple, intuitive commands with rich console output and comprehensive error handling Dual AI Provider Support Choose between Azure AI (remote) or Ollama (local) for processing Advanced Model Configuration Select from multiple AI models with availability validation Secure Authentication GitHub token-based authentication with secure local storage Flexible Output Customize output directory and filename options with intelligent fallbacks Local Processing Option Use Ollama for completely local, offline image processing

items.title: Quick Start
items.text:
Get up and running with Handmark in three simple steps:

pipuv 
# Install Handmark
pip install handmark

# Configure authentication
handmark auth

# Process your first image
handmark digest path/to/your/image.jpg

# Install Handmark with uv
uv pip install handmark

# Configure authentication
handmark auth

# Process your first image
handmark digest path/to/your/image.jpg

That's it!

Your handwritten notes will be converted to a Markdown file automatically.

items.title: Configuration
items.text: Handmark uses a centralized YAML configuration system that allows extensive customization of AI prompts, output formats, and model settings. This guide explains how to configure Handmark to suit your specific needs.

items.title: Configuration File Location
items.text:
The main configuration file is located at:

<project-root>/config.yaml

This file is included with your Handmark installation and controls:

  • AI model prompts and behavior
  • Output format settings
  • Available models and providers
  • Default preferences

items.title: Overview
items.text:
# AI Model Prompts
system_message_content: "..."
user_message_content: "..."

# Output Formats
formats:
  markdown: {...}
  json: {...}
  yaml: {...}
  xml: {...}

# Available Models
available_models:
  - name: "gpt-4o"
    ...

items.title: System Message Configuration
items.text: The system message defines how the AI interprets and processes your images.

items.title: Default Configuration
items.text:
system_message_content: |
  You are a highly skilled assistant specialized in converting 
  handwritten images into structured digital documents.

items.title: Academic Focus
items.text:
system_message_content: |
  You are an academic assistant specialized in converting 
  handwritten lecture notes and mathematical content. Pay special 
  attention to:
  - Mathematical notation and equations
  - Citation formats
  - Academic terminology
  - Proper LaTeX formatting

items.title: Business Focus
items.text:
system_message_content: |
  You are a business assistant specialized in converting 
  handwritten meeting notes and business documents. Focus on:
  - Action items and deadlines
  - Professional terminology
  - Organizational structure
  - Key decisions and outcomes

items.title: User Message Configuration
items.text: The user message tells the AI exactly what to do with the image.

items.title: Default Configuration
items.text:
user_message_content: |
  Convert the content of this handwritten image into a structured 
  document. Preserve formatting, mathematics, and structure.

items.title: Detailed Formatting
items.text:
user_message_content: |
  Convert this handwritten image with the following requirements:
  1. Maintain hierarchical structure (headings, subheadings)
  2. Convert math equations to LaTeX format
  3. Preserve lists and bullet points
  4. Extract dates in ISO 8601 format
  5. Identify and highlight action items

items.title: Language-Specific
items.text:
user_message_content: |
  Convert this Portuguese handwritten content to structured text.
  Maintain original language. Pay attention to:
  - Portuguese accents and diacritics
  - Brazilian vs European Portuguese variations
  - Technical terms in Portuguese

items.title: Format Configuration
items.text: Each output format has its own configuration section.

items.title: Markdown Format
items.text:
formats:
  markdown:
    file_extension: ".md"
    content_type: "text/markdown"
    system_message_content: |
      Convert handwritten content to clean Markdown format.
      Use proper heading hierarchy (# ## ###).
      Format code blocks with language specifiers.
      Convert equations to LaTeX ($...$).
    user_message_content: |
      Return only the Markdown content without additional commentary.

Customization options:

formats:
  markdown:
    # Add custom metadata
    include_metadata: true
    metadata_format: "yaml-frontmatter"

    # Enable/disable features
    enable_latex: true
    enable_code_blocks: true
    enable_tables: true

    # Heading style
    heading_style: "atx"  # or "setext"

items.title: JSON Format
items.text:
formats:
  json:
    file_extension: ".json"
    content_type: "application/json"
    indent: 2
    ensure_ascii: false

Customization options:

formats:
  json:
    # Formatting
    indent: 4  # Number of spaces for indentation
    ensure_ascii: false  # Allow UTF-8 characters
    sort_keys: true  # Sort keys alphabetically

    # Structure
    include_timestamp: true
    include_metadata: true
    nest_sections: true

items.title: YAML Format
items.text:
formats:
  yaml:
    file_extension: ".yaml"
    content_type: "text/yaml"
    default_flow_style: false

Customization options:

formats:
  yaml:
    # Formatting
    indent: 2
    width: 80  # Line width for wrapping
    default_flow_style: false

    # Features
    allow_unicode: true
    explicit_start: true  # Add --- at start
    explicit_end: false   # Add ... at end

items.title: XML Format
items.text:
formats:
  xml:
    file_extension: ".xml"
    content_type: "application/xml"
    encoding: "UTF-8"

Customization options:

formats:
  xml:
    # XML Declaration
    include_declaration: true
    encoding: "UTF-8"
    standalone: true

    # Formatting
    indent: "  "  # Two spaces
    pretty_print: true

    # Schema
    root_element: "document"
    namespace: "http://example.com/handmark"

items.title: Model Configuration
items.text: Define available AI models and their properties.

items.title: Azure AI Models
items.text:
available_models:
  - name: "gpt-4o"
    pretty_name: "GPT-4o"
    provider: "Azure OpenAI"
    rate_limit: "10000 requests/day"
    description: "Best overall accuracy for complex content"
    capabilities:
      - "vision"
      - "text-generation"
      - "math-notation"

  - name: "Phi-3.5-vision-instruct"
    pretty_name: "Phi-3.5 Vision"
    provider: "Azure OpenAI"
    rate_limit: "15000 requests/day"
    description: "Fast and efficient for general content"

items.title: Ollama Models
items.text:
available_models:
  - name: "llama3.2-vision"
    pretty_name: "Llama 3.2 Vision"
    provider: "Ollama"
    local: true
    description: "Local processing, no internet required"
    requirements:
      - "ollama >= 0.1.0"
      - "RAM >= 8GB"
      - "GPU recommended"

items.title: Adding Custom Models
items.text:
To add your own model:

available_models:
  - name: "custom-model-name"
    pretty_name: "My Custom Model"
    provider: "Custom Provider"
    endpoint: "https://api.custom-provider.com/v1"
    api_key_env: "CUSTOM_API_KEY"  # Environment variable name
    rate_limit: "5000 requests/day"
    description: "Custom model description"

items.title: Environment Variables
items.text: Sensitive configuration can be stored in environment variables.

items.title: .env File
items.text:
Create a .env file in your project root:

# Azure AI / GitHub Token
GITHUB_TOKEN=your_github_token_here

# Custom API Keys
CUSTOM_API_KEY=your_custom_key_here

# Advanced Settings
HANDMARK_LOG_LEVEL=INFO
HANDMARK_TIMEOUT=30
HANDMARK_MAX_RETRIES=3

Security Warning

Never commit .env files to version control! Add to .gitignore:

.env
.env.*
*.env

items.title: Supported Environment Variables
items.text: Variable Description Default GITHUB_TOKEN Authentication token for Azure AI None HANDMARK_LOG_LEVEL Logging verbosity (DEBUG, INFO, WARNING, ERROR) INFO HANDMARK_TIMEOUT Request timeout in seconds 30 HANDMARK_MAX_RETRIES Maximum retry attempts 3 HANDMARK_OUTPUT_DIR Default output directory Current directory HANDMARK_DEFAULT_FORMAT Default output format markdown

items.title: Rate Limiting
items.text:
Configure rate limiting to avoid API throttling:

rate_limiting:
  enabled: true
  max_requests_per_minute: 60
  max_requests_per_hour: 1000
  backoff_strategy: "exponential"
  max_backoff_time: 300  # seconds

items.title: Caching
items.text:
Enable caching to avoid reprocessing identical images:

caching:
  enabled: true
  cache_dir: ".handmark_cache"
  max_cache_size_mb: 100
  ttl_hours: 24  # Cache lifetime
  cache_strategy: "hash"  # or "filename"

items.title: Logging
items.text:
Customize logging behavior:

logging:
  level: "INFO"  # DEBUG, INFO, WARNING, ERROR, CRITICAL
  format: "%(asctime)s - %(levelname)s - %(message)s"
  file: "handmark.log"
  max_size_mb: 10
  backup_count: 5

items.title: Timeouts
items.text:
Configure timeout settings:

timeouts:
  connection: 10  # seconds
  read: 30  # seconds
  upload: 60  # seconds for large images

items.title: 1. Version Control
items.text:
Keep a template configuration in version control:

# config.template.yaml
system_message_content: "Default system message"
user_message_content: "Default user message"

# Users copy this to config.yaml and customize

items.title: 2. Profile-Based Configuration
items.text:
Create different profiles for different use cases:

config/
├── config.yaml          # Default
├── academic.yaml        # Academic focus
├── business.yaml        # Business focus
└── development.yaml     # Development/testing

Load specific profile:

HANDMARK_CONFIG=config/academic.yaml handmark digest image.jpg

items.title: 3. Validation
items.text:
Validate your configuration before use:

handmark config --validate

items.title: 4. Documentation
items.text:
Document your customizations:

# Custom Configuration for Project X
# Purpose: Academic paper digitization
# Modified: 2025-03-15
# Author: Your Name

system_message_content: |
  Custom message...

items.title: Configuration Not Loading
items.text:
1. Check file location: Ensure config.yaml is in the project root
  2. Check YAML syntax: Use a YAML validator
  3. Check permissions: Ensure the file is readable

items.title: Invalid Configuration
items.text:
Run configuration validation:

handmark config --validate

Common errors:

  • Invalid YAML syntax (indentation, special characters)
  • Missing required fields
  • Invalid model names
  • Incorrect data types

items.title: Configuration Changes Not Applied
items.text:
1. Restart the application after configuration changes
  2. Clear cache if caching is enabled
  3. Check environment variables that might override settings

items.title: Installation
items.text: This guide will help you install Handmark on your system. Handmark is distributed as a Python package and can be installed using various package managers.

items.title: Prerequisites
items.text:
Before installing Handmark, ensure you have the following:

System Requirements

  • Python: Version 3.10 or higher
  • Package Manager: pip (included with Python) or uv (recommended)
  • GitHub Token: Required for Azure AI access (can be configured after installation)

items.title: Check Python Version
items.text:
To verify your Python installation:

macOS / LinuxWindows 
python3 --version

python --version

Installing Python

If you don't have Python installed, visit the Python website and follow the Python Setup and Usage instructions for your operating system.

items.title: Install with pip
items.text:
The simplest way to install Handmark is using pip, Python's built-in package manager:

macOS / LinuxWindows 
# Optional: Create a virtual environment (recommended)
python3 -m venv .venv
source .venv/bin/activate

# Install Handmark
pip install handmark

# Optional: Create a virtual environment (recommended)
python -m venv .venv
.venv\Scripts\activate

# Install Handmark
pip install handmark

items.title: Install with uv
items.text:
If you're developing software using Python, you might be using uv as a package manager. To install Handmark with uv:

# Initialize uv project (if needed)
uv init

# Install Handmark
uv pip install handmark

Recommended for Developers

uv is faster and provides better dependency resolution than traditional pip. It's becoming the standard in the Python community.

items.title: Install from Source
items.text:
For development or to get the latest features, you can install directly from the GitHub repository:

# Clone the repository
git clone https://github.com/devgabrielsborges/handmark.git
cd handmark

# Install in editable mode
pip install -e .

Development Installation

Installing from source is intended for developers who want to contribute to Handmark or test unreleased features. For regular usage, install from PyPI using pip or uv.

items.title: Verify Installation
items.text:
After installation, verify that Handmark is correctly installed:

handmark --version

You should see output similar to:

Handmark version 0.5.0

items.title: Next Steps
items.text:
Now that Handmark is installed, you need to configure authentication:

  1. Configure GitHub Token: Run handmark auth to set up Azure AI access
  2. Select AI Model: Use handmark set-model to choose your preferred AI provider
  3. Process Your First Image: Try the Quick Start guide

Quick Start

Ready to start digitizing your handwritten notes? Check out the Quick Start Guide for a hands-on tutorial.

items.title: Updating Handmark
items.text:
To update Handmark to the latest version:

pipuv 
pip install --upgrade handmark

uv pip install --upgrade handmark

items.title: Uninstalling
items.text:
To remove Handmark from your system:

pipuv 
pip uninstall handmark

uv pip uninstall handmark

items.title: Common Issues
items.text:
Permission denied error

If you encounter a permission error during installation, try one of these solutions:

  • Use a virtual environment (recommended): 

    python3 -m venv .venv
source .venv/bin/activate
pip install handmark

  • Install for current user only: 

    pip install --user handmark

Python version error

If you see an error about Python version compatibility:

ERROR: Python 3.10 or higher is required

You need to upgrade your Python installation. Visit python.org to download the latest version.

Package not found

If pip cannot find the Handmark package:

  • Ensure you have an active internet connection
  • Update pip to the latest version: 
    pip install --upgrade pip
  • Try installing from the test PyPI repository: 
    pip install -i https://test.pypi.org/simple/ handmark

items.title: Getting Help
items.text:
If you encounter issues during installation:

  • Check the Troubleshooting guide for common problems

  • Create a new issue with details about your environment and the error message

items.title: Quick Start
items.text: Get started with Handmark in just a few minutes! This guide will walk you through the basic workflow of converting handwritten notes into digital documents.

items.title: Prerequisites
items.text:
Before starting, make sure you have:

  • Installed Handmark (Installation Guide)
  • A GitHub token for Azure AI access
  • An image of handwritten notes to process

Don't have a GitHub token yet?

Don't worry! The setup process below will guide you through obtaining one.

items.title: Step 1: Configure Authentication
items.text:
Handmark uses Azure AI services which require a GitHub token for authentication.

handmark auth

You'll be prompted to enter your GitHub token:

Enter your GitHub token (press Enter when done):

How to get a GitHub token?

  1. Go to GitHub Settings → Developer settings → Personal access tokens
  2. Click "Generate new token (classic)"
  3. Give it a descriptive name (e.g., "Handmark Access")
  4. Select necessary scopes (read access is sufficient)
  5. Click "Generate token" and copy it immediately
  6. Paste it into the Handmark prompt

The token will be securely stored in a .env file in your project directory.

items.title: Step 2: Select an AI Model
items.text:
Choose which AI provider and model you want to use:

handmark set-model

You'll see an interactive menu:

Available models:
1. GPT-4o (Azure OpenAI) [AVAILABLE]
2. Phi-3.5 Vision (Azure OpenAI) [AVAILABLE]
3. Llama 3.2 Vision (Ollama) [REQUIRES INSTALLATION]

Select a model (1-3):

Recommended for beginners

Start with GPT-4o (option 1) for the best results. It provides excellent handwriting recognition and handles complex mathematical notation.

items.title: About AI Providers
items.text:
Azure AI (Remote)Ollama (Local)

Pros:

  • High accuracy for complex content
  • No local setup required
  • Handles mathematical notation well

Cons:

  • Requires internet connection
  • Needs GitHub token authentication

Pros:

  • Completely offline processing
  • No authentication needed
  • Privacy-focused

Cons:

  • Requires local installation
  • May be slower on older hardware
  • Install from ollama.com

items.title: Step 3: Process Your First Image
items.text: Now you're ready to digitize your handwritten notes!

items.title: Basic Usage
items.text:
handmark digest path/to/your/image.jpg

The tool will:

  1. Upload your image to the AI service
  2. Process the handwritten content
  3. Extract and format the text
  4. Save it as a Markdown file

items.title: Example with Sample Image
items.text:
If you cloned the repository, try processing the included sample:

handmark digest samples/prova.jpeg

Sample image: Handwritten mathematics exam in Portuguese

Expected output:

Processing image: samples/prova.jpeg
✓ Image uploaded successfully
✓ Content extracted
✓ Title detected: Primeiro Exercício Escolar - 2025.1
✓ File saved: primeiro-exercicio-escolar-2025-1.md

Your first document!

Open the generated file to see your handwritten notes converted to formatted Markdown with proper LaTeX math equations!

items.title: Step 4: Explore Output Formats
items.text: Handmark supports multiple output formats beyond Markdown:

items.title: Markdown (Default)
items.text:
handmark digest image.jpg

Perfect for documentation, notes, and blog posts.

items.title: JSON
items.text:
handmark digest image.jpg -f json

Structured data format, great for:

  • Data processing pipelines
  • API integrations
  • Database storage

items.title: YAML
items.text:
handmark digest image.jpg -f yaml

Human-readable configuration format, ideal for:

  • Configuration files
  • Structured notes
  • Data serialization

items.title: XML
items.text:
handmark digest image.jpg -f xml

Enterprise-friendly format for:

  • Legacy system integration
  • Document management
  • Data exchange

items.title: Specify Output Directory
items.text: handmark digest image.jpg -o ./my-notes

items.title: Custom Filename
items.text: handmark digest image.jpg --filename lecture-notes-01.md

items.title: Combine Options
items.text: handmark digest image.jpg -o ./structured-data -f json --filename data.json

items.title: Processing Academic Notes
items.text:
# Process exam questions
handmark digest exam-questions.jpg -o ./exams

# Process lecture notes with custom name
handmark digest lecture.jpg -o ./lectures --filename calculus-2025-03-15.md

items.title: Creating Structured Data
items.text:
# Convert handwritten forms to JSON
handmark digest form.jpg -f json -o ./data

# Convert meeting notes to YAML
handmark digest meeting-notes.jpg -f yaml -o ./meetings

items.text:
Processing Multiple Images

Use shell loops to process multiple images:

Bash/ZshFish 
for img in *.jpg; do
    handmark digest "$img" -o ./processed
done

for img in *.jpg
    handmark digest $img -o ./processed
end

items.title: Quick Diagnostics
items.text:
Before diving into specific issues, run these diagnostic commands:

# Check version
handmark --version

# Check configuration
handmark config

# Check provider status
handmark status

# Test connection
handmark test-connection

items.title: Error: GitHub token not configured or invalid
items.text:
Symptom:

Error: GitHub token not configured or invalid
Please run 'handmark auth' to configure authentication

Solution:

  1. Run the authentication setup:

    handmark auth

  2. Enter a valid GitHub token when prompted

  3. Verify the token has appropriate permissions

Getting a GitHub Token

Visit GitHub Settings → Tokens to create a new personal access token. Read access is sufficient for Handmark.

items.title: Error: Authentication token expired
items.text:
Symptom:

Error: HTTP 401 - Unauthorized
Authentication token may be expired

Solution:

  1. Generate a new GitHub token
  2. Run handmark auth again
  3. Enter the new token

items.title: Environment Variable Not Found
items.text:
Symptom:

Error: GITHUB_TOKEN environment variable not found

Solution:

Check if .env file exists and contains your token:

# View .env file (be careful not to share this!)
cat .env

Should contain:

GITHUB_TOKEN=your_token_here

If missing, run handmark auth to create it.

items.title: Error: Connection timeout
items.text:
Symptom:

HTTPSConnectionPool(host='models.github.ai', port=443): Read timed out

Causes:

  • Slow internet connection
  • AI service experiencing high load
  • Firewall or proxy blocking connection
  • Image too large for processing

Solutions:

Solution 1: RetrySolution 2: Check ConnectionSolution 3: Use Local ProcessingSolution 4: Reduce Image Size

Wait a few minutes and try again. The service may be temporarily overloaded.

# Test connection
handmark test-connection

# Check if you can reach the service
ping models.github.ai

Switch to Ollama for offline processing:

handmark set-model
# Select an Ollama model

Resize large images before processing:

# Using ImageMagick
convert input.jpg -resize 2000x2000\> output.jpg

# Process the smaller image
handmark digest output.jpg

items.title: Error: Network unreachable
items.text:
Symptom:

Error: [Errno 101] Network is unreachable

Solution:

  1. Check your internet connection
  2. Verify network configuration
  3. Check firewall settings
  4. Try using a VPN if your network blocks the service
  5. Use Ollama for offline processing

items.title: Proxy Configuration
items.text:
If you're behind a corporate proxy:

# Set proxy environment variables
export HTTP_PROXY=http://proxy.company.com:8080
export HTTPS_PROXY=http://proxy.company.com:8080

# Then run handmark
handmark digest image.jpg

items.title: Error: No model configured
items.text:
Symptom:

Warning: No model configured. Using default model

Solution:

Select your preferred model:

handmark set-model

This is a warning, not an error. Handmark will use a default model, but explicitly selecting one is recommended.

items.title: Error: Model not available
items.text:
Symptom:

Error: Selected model 'llama3.2-vision' is not available
Ollama service may not be running or model not installed

Solution for Ollama:

  1. Install Ollama:

    Visit ollama.com and follow installation instructions

  2. Start Ollama service:

    # macOS/Linux
ollama serve

# Check if running
ollama list

  3. Pull the model:

    ollama pull llama3.2-vision

  4. Verify installation:

    handmark status

items.title: Error: Model rate limit exceeded
items.text:
Symptom:

Error: HTTP 429 - Too Many Requests
Rate limit exceeded for model

Solution:

  1. Wait and retry: Rate limits reset after a period
  2. Switch models: Try a different model with handmark set-model
  3. Use Ollama: No rate limits for local processing

items.title: Error: Unsupported image format
items.text:
Symptom:

Error: Unsupported image format: .heic
Supported formats: .jpg, .jpeg, .png, .gif, .bmp, .tiff, .webp

Solution:

Convert the image to a supported format:

# Using ImageMagick
convert input.heic output.jpg

# Or using Python
pip install pillow
python -c "from PIL import Image; Image.open('input.heic').save('output.jpg')"

# Then process
handmark digest output.jpg

items.title: Error: Image file not found
items.text:
Symptom:

Error: Image file not found: path/to/image.jpg

Solution:

  1. Check file path: Ensure the path is correct and file exists

    # List files to verify
ls -la path/to/

  2. Use absolute path: Try using the full path

    handmark digest /full/path/to/image.jpg

  3. Check permissions: Ensure file is readable

    chmod +r image.jpg

items.title: Poor Recognition Quality
items.text:
Symptom: Handmark produces inaccurate or incomplete results

Solutions:

Improve Image QualityPreprocess ImageTry Different ModelCrop to Content
  • Use higher resolution (minimum 1200x1600 pixels)
  • Ensure good lighting
  • Avoid shadows and glare
  • Take photo straight-on, not at an angle
  • Use high contrast (dark ink on light paper)
# Enhance contrast
convert input.jpg -contrast-stretch 0 output.jpg

# Remove noise
convert input.jpg -despeckle output.jpg

# Increase brightness
convert input.jpg -brightness-contrast 10x20 output.jpg

handmark set-model
# Try GPT-4o for best accuracy

Remove unnecessary borders and focus on the content area

items.title: Image Too Large
items.text:
Symptom:

Error: Image file size exceeds maximum (10MB)

Solution:

Reduce image file size:

# Reduce quality
convert input.jpg -quality 85 output.jpg

# Resize dimensions
convert input.jpg -resize 2000x2000\> output.jpg

# Both quality and size
convert input.jpg -resize 2000x2000\> -quality 85 output.jpg

items.title: Error: Permission denied writing output
items.text:
Symptom:

Error: [Errno 13] Permission denied: 'output.md'

Solution:

  1. Check directory permissions:

    ls -la output-directory/

  2. Make directory writable:

    chmod u+w output-directory/

  3. Try different output directory:

    handmark digest image.jpg -o ~/Documents/

items.title: Empty or Invalid Output
items.text:
Symptom: Generated file is empty or contains errors

Debugging steps:

  1. Check file contents:

    cat output-file.md

  2. Verify image processing:

    handmark test-connection
handmark status

  3. Try different format:

    # Try JSON for structured output
handmark digest image.jpg -f json

  4. Check logs:

    Enable debug logging:

    export HANDMARK_LOG_LEVEL=DEBUG
handmark digest image.jpg

items.title: Filename Issues
items.text:
Symptom: Generated filename contains special characters or is unreadable

Solution:

Specify a custom filename:

handmark digest image.jpg --filename custom-name.md

Or configure title extraction in config.yaml.

items.title: Error: Configuration file not found
items.text:
Symptom:

Error: Configuration file 'config.yaml' not found

Solution:

  1. Check working directory:

    pwd
ls -la | grep config

  2. Reinstall Handmark:

    pip install --force-reinstall handmark

  3. Create custom config:

    Copy from template or documentation

items.title: Error: Invalid YAML syntax
items.text:
Symptom:

Error: Error parsing config.yaml at line 15
yaml.scanner.ScannerError: mapping values are not allowed here

Solution:

  1. Validate YAML:

    Use an online YAML validator or:

    python -c "import yaml; yaml.safe_load(open('config.yaml'))"

  2. Common YAML issues:

    • Incorrect indentation (use spaces, not tabs)
    • Missing colons after keys
    • Unquoted special characters
    • Mismatched brackets/quotes

  3. Reset to default:

    # Backup your config
mv config.yaml config.yaml.backup

# Reinstall to get default
pip install --force-reinstall handmark

items.title: Gatekeeper Blocking
items.text:
Symptom: macOS prevents Handmark from running

Solution:

# Allow Handmark to run
xattr -d com.apple.quarantine $(which handmark)

items.title: SSL Certificate Errors
items.text:
Solution:

# Install certificates
/Applications/Python\ 3.x/Install\ Certificates.command

items.title: Path Length Limit
items.text:
Symptom: Errors with long file paths

Solution:

Enable long paths in Windows:

  1. Run as Administrator: gpedit.msc
  2. Navigate to: Local Computer Policy → Computer Configuration → Administrative Templates → System → Filesystem
  3. Enable "Enable Win32 long paths"

items.title: PowerShell Execution Policy
items.text:
Symptom: Cannot run handmark in PowerShell

Solution:

Set-ExecutionPolicy -ExecutionPolicy RemoteSigned -Scope CurrentUser

items.title: Missing Dependencies
items.text:
Solution:

# Debian/Ubuntu
sudo apt-get install python3-dev python3-pip

# Fedora/RHEL
sudo dnf install python3-devel python3-pip

# Arch
sudo pacman -S python python-pip

items.title: Slow Processing
items.text:
Causes and solutions:

Large ImagesSlow InternetComplex Content

Resize images before processing:

convert input.jpg -resize 2000x2000\> output.jpg

Use Ollama for local processing:

handmark set-model
# Select Ollama model

Complex mathematical notation or tables may take longer. This is normal.

items.title: High Memory Usage
items.text:
Solution:

Process images one at a time, or increase system memory.

items.title: Enable Debug Logging
items.text:
Get detailed information about what's happening:

export HANDMARK_LOG_LEVEL=DEBUG
handmark digest image.jpg 2>&1 | tee debug.log

Share debug.log when reporting issues.

items.title: Collect System Information
items.text:
When reporting issues, include:

# System info
uname -a

# Python version
python --version

# Handmark version
handmark --version

# Handmark status
handmark status

# pip list
pip list | grep handmark

items.text:
Include:

items.title: Usage Guide
items.text: This comprehensive guide covers all Handmark commands, options, and use cases. Use this as your reference for day-to-day operations.

items.title: Command Overview
items.text:
Handmark provides several commands to manage your handwriting digitization workflow:

Command Description handmark digest Convert handwritten images to digital formats handmark auth Configure GitHub token authentication handmark set-model Select and configure AI models handmark config View current configuration handmark status Check provider availability and model status handmark test-connection Test connection to AI services handmark --version Display version information handmark --help Show help information

items.title: Digest Command
items.text: The digest command is the main workhorse of Handmark, converting handwritten images into structured digital documents.

items.title: Basic Syntax
items.text: handmark digest <image_path> [options]

items.title: Arguments
items.text: image_path (required) Path to the handwritten image file you want to process

items.title: -o, --output <directory>
items.text:
Specify the output directory for the generated file.

handmark digest notes.jpg -o ./documents

Default Behavior

If not specified, the file is saved in the current directory.

items.title: -f, --format <format>
items.text:
Choose the output format for your digitized content.

Available formats:

  • markdown (default) - Standard Markdown with LaTeX support
  • json - Structured JSON format
  • yaml - YAML configuration format
  • xml - XML document format
# Generate JSON output
handmark digest notes.jpg -f json

# Generate YAML output
handmark digest notes.jpg -f yaml

# Generate XML output
handmark digest notes.jpg -f xml

items.title: --filename <name>
items.text:
Specify a custom filename for the output.

handmark digest notes.jpg --filename my-custom-name.md

Automatic Title Detection

If you don't specify a filename, Handmark automatically extracts a title from the content and uses it for the filename. Special characters are normalized, and the title is converted to a URL-friendly format.

items.title: Example 1: Basic Conversion
items.text:
handmark digest samples/prova.jpeg

What happens:

  1. Image is processed using the configured AI model
  2. Title is automatically extracted: "Primeiro Exercício Escolar - 2025.1"
  3. Complex mathematical equations are converted to LaTeX
  4. File is saved as: primeiro-exercicio-escolar-2025-1.md

items.title: Example 2: Custom Output Location
items.text:
handmark digest lecture-notes.jpg -o ./course-materials/week-5

Saves the output to a specific directory structure.

items.title: Example 3: JSON for Data Processing
items.text:
handmark digest form-data.jpg -f json -o ./data --filename survey-001.json

Perfect for integrating with data pipelines or databases.

items.title: Example 4: All Options Combined
items.text:
handmark digest meeting-notes.jpg \
    -o ./meetings/2025-03 \
    -f markdown \
    --filename team-meeting-2025-03-15.md

items.title: Supported Image Formats
items.text:
Handmark supports common image formats:

  • JPEG / JPG
  • PNG
  • GIF (static)
  • BMP
  • TIFF
  • WebP

Image Quality

For best results, use high-resolution images (at least 1200x1600 pixels) with good lighting and contrast. Avoid blurry or low-contrast images.

items.title: Markdown Format
items.text:
The default format, perfect for documentation and note-taking.

Features:

  • Automatic heading detection
  • LaTeX math equation support (\(...\))
  • Proper paragraph formatting
  • Code block preservation
  • List structure maintenance

Example output:

# Meeting Notes - Q1 Planning

## Action Items

1. Review budget proposal
2. Schedule team meeting
3. Update project timeline

## Key Decisions

The team agreed to:

- Prioritize feature X
- Allocate resources to project Y

items.title: JSON Format
items.text:
Structured data format for programmatic processing.

Features:

  • Hierarchical structure
  • Type-safe values
  • Easy parsing in any language
  • Database-ready

Example output:

{
  "title": "Meeting Notes - Q1 Planning",
  "sections": [
    {
      "heading": "Action Items",
      "items": [
        "Review budget proposal",
        "Schedule team meeting",
        "Update project timeline"
      ]
    }
  ]
}

items.title: YAML Format
items.text:
Human-readable configuration format.

Features:

  • Clean, minimal syntax
  • Easy to edit manually
  • Configuration-friendly
  • Widely supported

Example output:

title: Meeting Notes - Q1 Planning
sections:
  - heading: Action Items
    items:
      - Review budget proposal
      - Schedule team meeting
      - Update project timeline

items.title: XML Format
items.text:
Enterprise-standard format for system integration.

Features:

  • Schema validation support
  • Wide tool support
  • Legacy system compatibility
  • Structured document format

Example output:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<document>
  <title>Meeting Notes - Q1 Planning</title>
  <section>
    <heading>Action Items</heading>
    <items>
      <item>Review budget proposal</item>
      <item>Schedule team meeting</item>
      <item>Update project timeline</item>
    </items>
  </section>
</document>

items.title: Azure AI Models
items.text:
These models run on Microsoft's cloud infrastructure:

GPT-4o

  • Best overall accuracy
  • Excellent with mathematical notation
  • Strong handwriting recognition
  • Requires internet connection
  • Requires GitHub token

Phi-3.5 Vision

  • Good balance of speed and accuracy
  • Lower latency than GPT-4o
  • May struggle with complex equations
  • Requires internet connection

items.title: Ollama Models (Local)
items.text:
These models run entirely on your local machine:

Llama 3.2 Vision

  • Completely offline
  • No authentication needed
  • Privacy-focused
  • Requires powerful hardware
  • Slower processing

Installation:

# Install Ollama from ollama.com
# Then pull the model:
ollama pull llama3.2-vision

items.title: Batch Processing
items.text:
Process multiple images in a directory:

Bash/ZshPython Script 
#!/bin/bash

# Process all JPG images in a directory
for image in ./scans/*.jpg; do
    echo "Processing: $image"
    handmark digest "$image" -o ./processed
done

import subprocess
from pathlib import Path

# Process all images in directory
scan_dir = Path("./scans")
output_dir = Path("./processed")

for image in scan_dir.glob("*.jpg"):
    print(f"Processing: {image}")
    subprocess.run([
        "handmark", "digest", str(image),
        "-o", str(output_dir)
    ])

items.title: Format Conversion Pipeline
items.text:
Convert handwritten notes to multiple formats:

#!/bin/bash

IMAGE="$1"
BASENAME=$(basename "$IMAGE" | sed 's/\.[^.]*$//')

# Create output directory
mkdir -p "./output/$BASENAME"

# Generate all formats
handmark digest "$IMAGE" -f markdown -o "./output/$BASENAME"
handmark digest "$IMAGE" -f json -o "./output/$BASENAME"
handmark digest "$IMAGE" -f yaml -o "./output/$BASENAME"
handmark digest "$IMAGE" -f xml -o "./output/$BASENAME"

echo "✓ Processed $IMAGE to all formats"

items.title: Integration with Git
items.text:
Track changes to your digitized notes:

#!/bin/bash

# Process image
handmark digest "$1" -o ./notes

# Commit to git
cd notes
git add .
git commit -m "Add digitized notes from $(date +%Y-%m-%d)"
git push

items.title: Quality Assurance Script
items.text:
Validate output quality:

#!/bin/bash

IMAGE="$1"
OUTPUT_DIR="./validated"

# Process image
handmark digest "$IMAGE" -o "$OUTPUT_DIR"

# Check if file was created
if [ $? -eq 0 ]; then
    echo "✓ Processing successful"

    # Check file size (should be > 0)
    LATEST_FILE=$(ls -t "$OUTPUT_DIR"/*.md | head -1)
    FILE_SIZE=$(wc -c < "$LATEST_FILE")

    if [ "$FILE_SIZE" -gt 0 ]; then
        echo "✓ Output file is valid (${FILE_SIZE} bytes)"
    else
        echo "✗ Output file is empty"
        exit 1
    fi
else
    echo "✗ Processing failed"
    exit 1
fi

items.title: Optimizing Image Files
items.text:
For best performance and accuracy:

  1. Resolution: Use at least 1200x1600 pixels
  2. Format: JPEG with 85% quality is optimal
  3. Size: Keep files under 10MB for faster upload
  4. Preprocessing: Crop unnecessary borders

items.title: Speed Considerations
items.text:
Faster:

  • Smaller images (while maintaining readability)
  • Ollama local models (no network latency)
  • PNG format (less decoding overhead)

Slower:

  • Very high resolution images (> 4K)
  • Complex mathematical notation
  • Multiple pages in one image
  • Poor image quality requiring multiple retries
